articles.headline: As Its I.P.O. Nears, Alibaba Gets Ready for a Splashy Debut
articles.snippet: The company, which runs two huge online marketplaces in China, plans to kick off a long-awaited roadshow for potential investors on Monday.
articles.abstract: The company, which runs two huge online marketplaces in China, plans to kick off a long-awaited roadshow for potential investors on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:55 p.m. | It began as a small Internet upstart in China, but now the Alibaba Group is preparing for a splashy debutante party that will stretch from New York to Hong Kong and back again.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: The Question of Coverage for Ride Service Drivers
articles.snippet: Two companies that bring together drivers of private cars and potential passengers have been battling over who provides insurance, and when.
articles.abstract: Two companies that bring together drivers of private cars and potential passengers have been battling over who provides insurance, and when.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is a pervasive attitude in a prominent corner of the technology industry that goes something like this: If you’re helping people rent (not share, rent) spare bedrooms or rides in their cars, then the usual regulations and niggling insurance issues should not apply. Entrepreneurs start useful services, attract millions of users, cross their fingers and hope nobody dies before the government minders and other scolds catch up.

articles.headline: Silicon Valley Fights Order to Pay Bigger Settlement in Hiring Case
articles.snippet: Google, Apple, Intel and Adobe filed papers asking the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals to spurn Judge Lucy H. Koh’s rejection of their $324.5 million antitrust settlement as too meager.
articles.abstract: Google, Apple, Intel and Adobe filed papers asking the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals to spurn Judge Lucy H. Koh’s rejection of their $324.5 million antitrust settlement as too meager.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Silicon Valley is holding on tight to its wallet.

articles.headline: Two Cities With Blazing Internet Speed Search for a Killer App
articles.snippet: Both Kansas City, Mo., and Kansas City, Kan., have Google Fiber, a high-speed fiber-optic network, and are having a hard time figuring out what to do with so much power.
articles.abstract: Both Kansas City, Mo., and Kansas City, Kan., have Google Fiber, a high-speed fiber-optic network, and are having a hard time figuring out what to do with so much power.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — A team of computer programmers here set out to learn how many cute kitten photos can be downloaded in one second on their Internet network, one of the fastest in the country.

articles.headline: In Remote Detention Center, a Battle on Fast Deportations
articles.snippet: A corps of volunteers is changing the nature and purpose of a temporary outpost that the Obama administration set up to hold illegal immigrants briefly until they could be deported.
articles.abstract: A corps of volunteers is changing the nature and purpose of a temporary outpost that the Obama administration set up to hold illegal immigrants briefly until they could be deported.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARTESIA, N.M. — Sitting before a small video screen in a bare room in a remote corner of New Mexico, a young Honduran woman told her story this week to an immigration judge in Virginia. She had been serially raped, she said, spat upon and relentlessly hounded by a drug-dealing husband who regarded her as his property.

articles.headline: Obama Delays Immigration Action, Yielding to Democratic Concerns
articles.snippet: In putting off action until after the November elections, President Obama was acting out of concern for Senate Democrats on the ballots, White House officials said on Saturday.
articles.abstract: In putting off action until after the November elections, President Obama was acting out of concern for Senate Democrats on the ballots, White House officials said on Saturday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will delay taking executive action on immigration until after the midterm elections, bowing to pressure from fellow Democrats who feared that acting now could doom his party’s chances this fall, White House officials said on Saturday.

articles.headline: At Goldman Sachs, Even the Legal Fees Are Different
articles.snippet: The company’s corporate bylaws are ambiguous about paying employees’ legal fees.
articles.abstract: The company’s corporate bylaws are ambiguous about paying employees’ legal fees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs has the reputation of being a breed apart on Wall Street. Its employees are smarter, hungrier and quicker to the draw than those at rival firms. Thanks to these differences, Goldman sits at the apex of the nation’s investment banking hierarchy.

articles.headline: The Jack Ma Way
articles.snippet: Alibaba, started by Jack Ma in 1999, is about to sell shares in the United States that could value the company at about $160 billion.
articles.abstract: Alibaba, started by Jack Ma in 1999, is about to sell shares in the United States that could value the company at about $160 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the resplendent China World Hotel in Beijing, scores of cameras snapped as colorful confetti floated down from the ceiling. It was Aug. 11, 2005, and this was the global coming-out party for Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce upstart. After months of frantic negotiations, the American Internet giant Yahoo had agreed to invest $1 billion in cash and create deeper business ties, in exchange for a 40 percent stake in Alibaba.

articles.headline: Just 13, and Working Risky 12-Hour Shifts in the Tobacco Fields
articles.snippet: Public health experts say hundreds of children under 16 continue to work in America’s tobacco fields, where they are exposed to harmful chemicals like nicotine.
articles.abstract: Public health experts say hundreds of children under 16 continue to work in America’s tobacco fields, where they are exposed to harmful chemicals like nicotine.
articles.lead_paragraph: PINK HILL, N.C. — On many mornings, as tobacco plants tower around her, Saray Cambray Alvarez pulls a black plastic garbage bag over her 13-year-old body to protect her skin from leaves dripping with nicotine-tinged dew.

articles.headline: Challenging the President ... but Only on the Golf Course
articles.snippet: Marvin Nicholson, the White House travel director, who has played golf with the president about 140 times, rounds out the president’s foursomes and soothes his frayed feelings.
articles.abstract: Marvin Nicholson, the White House travel director, who has played golf with the president about 140 times, rounds out the president’s foursomes and soothes his frayed feelings.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At age 4, Marvin Nicholson hit his first golf ball on the nine-hole course his father had mowed into the front of the family’s farm in Ontario. By 7, he had won a Canada Dry Ginger Ale trophy for sinking a hole in one at the local public course. He caddied through college, carried Senator John Kerry’s clubs in Nantucket and then lugged so many of Mr. Kerry’s bags during the 2004 presidential campaign that he distributed business cards stamped with “Chief of Stuff.”

articles.headline: For Jihad Recruits, a Pipeline From Minnesota to Militancy
articles.snippet: The intertwined journeys of two friends toward militancy offer a sharp example of how the allure of Islamist extremism has evolved, enticing similar pools of young Americans to conflicts in different parts of the world.
articles.abstract: The intertwined journeys of two friends toward militancy offer a sharp example of how the allure of Islamist extremism has evolved, enticing similar pools of young Americans to conflicts in different parts of the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — It was a friendship that began in high school and ended in militant jihad.

articles.headline: Refugees Reshape Their Camp, at the Risk of Feeling at Home
articles.snippet: The construction of a public square in a deeply conservative Palestinian refugee camp has made some there feel more at home, a provocative concept in camps conceived as temporary.
articles.abstract: The construction of a public square in a deeply conservative Palestinian refugee camp has made some there feel more at home, a provocative concept in camps conceived as temporary.
articles.lead_paragraph: AL FAWWAR, West Bank — Up a rutted alley, mothers in head scarves, seated under flapping cloth canopies, sip tea and weave baskets. They’ve gathered in a dusty, sun-bleached square, not much bigger than a pocket park, made of limestone and concrete, shoehorned into a warren of low, concrete and cinder-block houses. The square isn’t much to look at.

articles.headline: Foreign Powers Buy Influence at Think Tanks
articles.snippet: Prominent Washington think tanks, nonprofits known for their impartiality, have received tens of millions of dollars from foreign governments while pushing United States government officials to adopt policies that often reflect the donors’ priorit...
articles.abstract: Prominent Washington think tanks, nonprofits known for their impartiality, have received tens of millions of dollars from foreign governments while pushing United States government officials to adopt policies that often reflect the donors’ priorities, an investigation by The New York Times has found.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The agreement signed last year by the Norway Ministry of Foreign Affairs was explicit: For $5 million, Norway’s partner in Washington would push top officials at the White House, at the Treasury Department and in Congress to double spending on a United States foreign aid program.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton, Brooke Williams and Nicholas Confessore

articles.headline: With Videos of Killings, ISIS Sends Medieval Message by Modern Method
articles.snippet: The videos serve as both propaganda and time machine, trying to wipe away centuries of civilization and suggest that the dreamed-of caliphate flourishes and blood is cheap currency.
articles.abstract: The videos serve as both propaganda and time machine, trying to wipe away centuries of civilization and suggest that the dreamed-of caliphate flourishes and blood is cheap currency.
articles.lead_paragraph: The ostensible purpose of the recent videos that show the beheadings of two American journalists by Islamic militants is to deter attacks — your missiles on our positions will beget our knives on Western hostages — but the true aim is to spread dread and terror.

articles.headline: Success of Apple’s iWatch May Rely on Health Care Partnerships
articles.snippet: Just as the iPod’s appeal relied in part on Apple’s music industry relationships, the future of its new wrist device may rest on courting health companies.
articles.abstract: Just as the iPod’s appeal relied in part on Apple’s music industry relationships, the future of its new wrist device may rest on courting health companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple is trying to have another iPod experience.

articles.headline: Airlines Take the Bump Out of Turbulence
articles.snippet: Stronger computing power, improved satellite and radar technology and more sophisticated scientific models give airlines a greater understanding of flying conditions.
articles.abstract: Stronger computing power, improved satellite and radar technology and more sophisticated scientific models give airlines a greater understanding of flying conditions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just a few years ago, airlines got their weather reports by telex. Pilots pored over reams of paper and compared the forecasts with their flight plans. Once airborne, they depended on radio communications and rudimentary radar to avoid bad weather.

articles.headline: Filmmaker Pins Hopes on a Beach Boy
articles.snippet: William M. Pohlad, a movie producer and heir to a family fortune, hopes his second feature film directing effort in 24 years, a biopic about the Beach Boy Brian Wilson, is a charm.
articles.abstract: William M. Pohlad, a movie producer and heir to a family fortune, hopes his second feature film directing effort in 24 years, a biopic about the Beach Boy Brian Wilson, is a charm.
articles.lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The film producer William M. Pohlad has made his name in Hollywood backing award-winning films like “12 Years a Slave” and “Brokeback Mountain.” But he first tried his hand at directing, and his 1990 debut feature, “Old Explorers,” went virtually unseen, losing money for friends and family.

articles.headline: Destroying ISIS May Take Years, U.S. Officials Say
articles.snippet: The Obama administration is preparing to carry out a phased campaign requiring a sustained effort that could last until after President Obama has left office, according to officials.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration is preparing to carry out a phased campaign requiring a sustained effort that could last until after President Obama has left office, according to officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is preparing to carry out a campaign against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria that may take three years to complete, requiring a sustained effort that could last until after President Obama has left office, according to senior administration officials.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt, Michael R. Gordon and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: G.M.’s Board Is Seen as Slow in Reacting to Safety Crisis
articles.snippet: The automaker’s directors were caught off guard by the extent of the problems that led to the recall of millions of vehicles, but their chairman says they are now “very much involved” in the situation.
articles.abstract: The automaker’s directors were caught off guard by the extent of the problems that led to the recall of millions of vehicles, but their chairman says they are now “very much involved” in the situation.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — After General Motors emerged from bankruptcy and a government bailout five years ago, the board of directors of the “new G.M.” was expected to keep a more watchful eye on a company that had gone seriously off track.

articles.headline: Qatar’s Support of Islamists Alienates Allies Near and Far
articles.snippet: Qatar has helped support a spectrum of Islamist groups by providing safe haven, diplomatic mediation, financial aid and, in certain instances, weapons.
articles.abstract: Qatar has helped support a spectrum of Islamist groups by providing safe haven, diplomatic mediation, financial aid and, in certain instances, weapons.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Standing at the front of a conference hall in Doha, the visiting sheikh told his audience of wealthy Qataris that to help the battered residents of Syria, they should not bother with donations to humanitarian programs or the Western-backed Free Syrian Army.

articles.headline: As Two Men Go Free, a Dogged Ex-Prosecutor Digs In
articles.snippet: Two innocent men were sent to death row while a serial sex offender who lived less than 100 yards from the crime scene was never seriously pursued as a suspect.
articles.abstract: Two innocent men were sent to death row while a serial sex offender who lived less than 100 yards from the crime scene was never seriously pursued as a suspect.
articles.lead_paragraph: LUMBERTON, N.C. — The most memorable moment of the trial that put Henry McCollum and Leon Brown behind bars for three decades for a hideous 1983 rape and murder was a display of brilliant courtroom theatrics.

articles.headline: Facebook’s Feeds Give Videos a Boost
articles.snippet: Facebook is announcing new tools for video producers, as use of the network to share video grows.
articles.abstract: Facebook is announcing new tools for video producers, as use of the network to share video grows.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — On Friday morning, Beyoncé posted a video on Facebook and YouTube that took her fans behind the scenes to see the preparations for her live performance last month at the MTV Video Music Awards.

articles.headline: Boom in Energy Spurs Industry in the Rust Belt
articles.snippet: Once-decayed steel towns and desolate rural regions are rising anew, their economies bustling as domestic oil and gas production surges.
articles.abstract: Once-decayed steel towns and desolate rural regions are rising anew, their economies bustling as domestic oil and gas production surges.
articles.lead_paragraph: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio — Waist-high weeds and a crumbling old Chevy mark the entrance to a rust-colored factory complex on the edge of town here, seemingly another monument to the passing of the golden age of American industry.
